question.text: Which of the following is paramagnetic?

solution.text:
Key Idea If all the electron in a molecule are paired, the molecule is diamagnetic and if there are unpaired electrons in a molecule, it is paramagnetic.
Molecular orbital configuration of given molecules are as follows:
(1) $\mathrm{N}_2(\mathrm{Z}=14)-\sigma \mathrm{ls}^2, \sigma^* 1 \mathrm{~s}^2, \sigma 2 \mathrm{~s}^2, \sigma{ }^* 2 \mathrm{~s}^2, \pi 2 \mathrm{p}_{\mathrm{x}}^2$ $=\pi 2 \mathrm{p}_{\mathrm{y}}^2, \sigma 2 \mathrm{p}_{\mathrm{z}}^2$
It is a diamagnetic molecule due to absence of unpaired electron.
(2) $\mathrm{H}_2(\mathrm{Z}=2)-1 \sigma^2$
It is a diamagnetic molecule.
(3) $\mathrm{Li}_2(\mathrm{Z}=6)-\sigma \mathrm{ls}^2, \sigma{ }^* 1 \mathrm{~s}^2, \sigma 2 \mathrm{~s}^2$
It is a diamagnetic molecule.
(4) $\mathrm{O}_2(\mathrm{Z}=16)-\sigma \mathrm{ls}^2, \sigma{ }^* 1 \mathrm{~s}^2, \sigma 2 \mathrm{~s}^2, \sigma * 2 \mathrm{~s}^2$,
$$
\sigma 2 p_z^2, \pi 2 p_x^2=\pi 2 p_y^2, \pi * 2 p_x^1=\pi * 2 p_y^1
$$
It is a paramagnetic molecule due to presence of unpaired electrons in each orbital of degenerate levels.
Thus, option (4) is correct.
